description.narrative: A 5-year advocacy programme to support women’s movements in Ethiopia, Kenya and Uganda to be strengthened, less fragmented and more representative of diverse groups of women, including women with disabilities. These stronger women’s movements will contribute to strong women leaders at all levels, and the prevention and elimination of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) against women and girls.

title.narrative: An increase in the number and diversity of women supported with training, awareness-raising, and networking
Number of women supported with training, awareness-raising, and networking

description.narrative: Self 1.5: # women have increased understanding of feminist principles and approaches to diversity and inclusion.

comment.narrative:
In the baseline, 306 women had an appreciation of basic feminist statements and principles and approaches to diversity and inclusion, but lack a deeper understanding of applying them to ensure gender equality: so the baseline value is 0.
The targeted women are: 1100 women from the women's groups, 348 women reached in transformative leadership trainings and 89 women leaders at national & sub-national level

1000 women have increased understanding of feminist principles and approaches to diversity and inclusion. The targeted women by end of AWESOME are: 1100 women from the women's groups, 348 women reached in transformative leadership trainings and 89 women leaders at national & sub-national level

Our post training evaluations from training of women in groups showed that 1,057 women have increased understanding of feminist principles and approaches (57 more women than anticipated). 29 members of parliament, 40 district councillors and 22 resident resource persons, who received extensive training also showed increased understanding of feminist principles and approaches

150 women have increased understanding of feminist principles and approaches to diversity and inclusion. The targeted women are: 1100 women from the women's groups, 348 women reached in transformative leadership trainings and 89 women leaders at national & sub-national level

150 women have increased understanding of feminist principles and approaches to diversity and inclusion. The targeted women are: 1100 women from the women's groups, 348 women reached in transformative leadership trainings and 89 women leaders at national & sub-national level

150 women have increased understanding of feminist principles and approaches to diversity and inclusion. The targeted women are: 1100 women from the women's groups, 348 women reached in transformative leadership trainings and 89 women leaders at national & sub-national level

In total, 1,537 women have increased understanding of feminist principles and approaches to diversity and inclusion. The targeted women are: 1100 women from the women's groups, 348 women reached in transformative leadership trainings and 89 women leaders at national & sub-national level

title.narrative: An increase in gender-sensitive and disability-inclusive coverage and reporting in the media
Number of media spots that promote women’s (including WwDs) rights related to SGBV

description.narrative: Society 2.6: Evidence of the voices of marginalised women included in media campaigns

comment.narrative:
No content has been produced within AWESOME yet (so the baseline value is 0).
Voices will influence debate, as well as act as the evidence needed for gender responsive service delivery for SGBV, form basis for conversation around positive masculinity.

20 media campaigns inclusive of women's voices (16 Days, and other moments and media, petitions). The campaigns are characterised by women setting the agenda, influencing the debate, and/or movement building, shining a light on the SGBV and women's leadership stories for visibility and increased awareness.
These will run across national and subnational levels for a wider audience but change will be measured at subnational level.
When we say that we want to amplify the voices of ‘diverse women’ we refer to the women that Womankind and partners are working with, including (and recognising that many women involved cross intersections of these groups) women with disabilities, internally displaced women, young women, aspiring and newly elected women leaders, women in rural areas, women industrial workers, women affected by conflict, survivors of SGBV, community leaders (not necessarily elected or aspirants but functioning in different spaces), informal workers (working on the fringes of the industrial zones and reached through the programme in Ethiopia for example), and WHRDs (includes women working within partner organisations).

title.narrative: Increased collective advocacy efforts by women's rights organisation (WRO) actors for policy change and legal reform, national and regional level
Number of influencing spaces attended or facilitated related to SGBV and participation

description.narrative: Self 1.9: Number of issues generated by women leaders (raised in grassroots community spaces, and then addressed in budgets, bylaws, policies, etc.)

comment.narrative:
Women leaders generate issues and table them in meetings, district councils and other forums for discussion. A major challenge is the lack of adequate statistics and information to present such issues in a more compelling manner to trigger policy actions by the local leaders.
Much as FOWODE had had interventions in these two districts, efforts were geared towards gender responsive service delivery through monitoring of public service points. This approach is new and therefore baseline is 0

25 issues generated by women leaders (raised in grassroots community spaces, and then addressed in budgets, bylaws, policies at sub-county and district levels, etc.). Legislation around SGBV, service delivery and women's leadership.
All will be measured at subnational level (District and sub county levels)
